articles.title: Neanderthals and early humans may have interbred over a vast area
articles.summary: We are getting a clearer sense of where and how often Homo sapiens and Neanderthals interbred, and it turns out the behaviour was much more common than we first thought
articles.content:
We are getting a clearer sense of where and how often Homo sapiens and Neanderthals interbred, and it turns out the behaviour was much more common than we first thought

An artist’s impression of Neanderthal life CHRISTIAN JEGOU/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Homo sapiens and Neanderthals were probably interbreeding over a huge area stretching from western Europe into Asia.

We have long known that early humans (Homo sapiens) and Neanderthals (Homo neanderthalensis) interbred, which is why most non-African people today have some Neanderthal DNA, typically about 2 per cent of their genome. The interbreeding also saw the Neanderthal Y chromosome lineages replaced by lineages from H. sapiens.

But where this interbreeding happened and on what kind of scale has long been a mystery, even if we are now starting to get a handle on when it occurred. The ancestors of Neanderthals left Africa about 600,000 years ago, heading into Europe and western Asia. And the earliest evidence of H. sapiens migrating out of Africa is skeletal remains from sites in modern day Israel and Greece, dating back around 200,000 years.

There are signs that H. sapiens contributed genetically to Neanderthal populations from the Altai mountains in what is now Siberia roughly 100,000 years ago, but the main pulse of their migration out of Africa came after about 60,000 years ago. Two studies from 2024 based on ancient genomes implied that the most gene flow between H. sapiens and Neanderthals happened in a sustained period of between around 4000 and 7000 years, starting about 50,000 years ago.

It was thought that this probably happened in the eastern Mediterranean region, but the location is hard to pin down.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

To investigate, Mathias Currat at the University of Geneva in Switzerland and his colleagues have used data from 4147 ancient genetic samples, the oldest being about 44,000 years old, which come from more than 1200 locations. They assessed the proportion of genetic variants from Neanderthal DNA – called introgressed alleles – that have been repeatedly transferred by hybridisation.

“The idea was to see whether it is possible using the patterns of Neanderthal DNA integration in past human genomes to see where integration took place,” says Currat.

The results show a gradual increase in the proportion of transferred DNA the further you go from the eastern Mediterranean region, which plateaus after about 3900 kilometres both westwards towards Europe and eastwards into Asia.

“We were quite surprised to see a nice increasing pattern of introgression proportion in human genomes resulting from what we guess is the out-of-Africa human expansion,” says Currat. “It’s increasing toward Europe, it’s increasing toward East Asia, and so it allows us to estimate the boundary of this hybrid zone.”

The researcher’s computer simulations indicate a hybrid zone that covered most of Europe and the eastern Mediterranean and went into western Asia.

The interbreeding zone between Neanderthals and H. sapiens. The dots represent the location of genetic samples analysed in the study and the triangle shows the possible route H. sapiens took out of Africa Lionel N. Di Santo et al. 2026

“What we see seems to be a single continuous pulse – a continuous series of interbreeding events in space and time,” says Currat. “However, we don’t know when hybridisation took place in the zone.”

The hybrid zone includes almost all known sites associated with Neanderthal fossils, spanning western Eurasia, except those from the Altai region.

“The finding that the inferred hybrid zone extends broadly into western Eurasia is intriguing and suggests that interactions between populations may have been geographically widespread,” says Leonardo Iasi at the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Leipzig, Germany.

However, the Atlantic fringe, including western France and most of the Iberian peninsula, isn’t in the hybrid zone, despite the well-documented Neanderthal presence there. It could be that there was no hybridisation in this region, says Currat, or that any interbreeding occurring here isn’t represented in the 4147 genetic samples.

“Overall, the study paints a picture of repeated interactions between modern humans and Neanderthals across a broad geographic range and over extended periods of time,” says Iasi, adding that the hybrid zone might extend further, but limited ancient DNA sampling in regions such as the Arabian peninsula makes it difficult to assess how far it went in that direction.

“This is an important paper that challenges the view that there was only one region, probably western Asia, and one Neanderthal population (not represented in the current Neanderthal genetic samples) that hybridised with the Homo sapiens population dispersing from Africa,” says Chris Stringer at the Natural History Museum in London. “As early sapiens spread out in ever-growing numbers and over an ever-expanding range, it seems they mopped up small Neanderthal populations they encountered along the way, across virtually the whole known Neanderthal range.”
articles.reasoning: The article reveals significant new scientific understanding about the widespread interbreeding between Homo sapiens and Neanderthals across a vast geographic area, which enriches our knowledge of human ancestry and evolution. This discovery has broad significance for humanity as a whole, offering a unifying perspective on human origins and shared heritage. The article provides detailed context and evidence from extensive ancient DNA analysis, making it a substantive and meaningful advancement in anthropology and genetics.
articles.personality_title: New study shows Neanderthals and early humans interbred across a vast region
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have known for some time that early humans, called Homo sapiens, and Neanderthals, a closely related group, interbred. This is why most people outside Africa have some Neanderthal DNA. However, where and how often this mixing happened was unclear.

**What happened** – Researchers from the University of Geneva studied 4,147 ancient human DNA samples from over 1,200 locations, some as old as 44,000 years. They looked for Neanderthal DNA mixed into early human genomes to find where interbreeding took place. Their analysis showed that the mixing happened over a large area stretching from western Europe through the eastern Mediterranean and into western Asia.

**Impact** – This finding is important because it shows that Neanderthals and early humans didn’t just meet and mix in one small place but across a wide region for thousands of years. It changes how we understand human history by revealing a broad “hybrid zone” where populations met and shared genes. This helps explain why Neanderthal DNA is found in many people today.

**What's next step** – Scientists want to study more ancient DNA from less explored areas like the Arabian Peninsula to see if the hybrid zone was even bigger. They also aim to learn exactly when and how often these interbreeding events happened.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Early humans and Neanderthals interbred repeatedly across much of Europe and Asia, creating a wide area of shared ancestry.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle étude montre que les Néandertaliens et les premiers humains se sont croisés sur une vaste région
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques savent depuis un moment que les premiers humains, appelés Homo sapiens, et les Néandertaliens, un groupe proche, se sont croisés. C’est pourquoi la plupart des personnes hors d’Afrique ont de l’ADN néandertalien. Mais on ne savait pas où et à quelle fréquence cela s’est produit.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Genève ont étudié 4 147 anciens échantillons d’ADN humain provenant de plus de 1 200 endroits, certains vieux de 44 000 ans. Ils ont cherché de l’ADN néandertalien dans les génomes humains anciens pour savoir où les croisements ont eu lieu. Leur analyse montre que ce mélange s’est produit sur une grande zone allant de l’Europe de l’Ouest, en passant par la Méditerranée orientale jusqu’à l’Asie occidentale.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle montre que Néandertaliens et premiers humains ne se sont pas croisés en un seul endroit, mais sur une vaste région pendant des milliers d’années. Cela change notre compréhension de l’histoire humaine en révélant une large « zone hybride » où les populations se sont rencontrées et ont partagé leurs gènes. Cela explique pourquoi l’ADN néandertalien est présent chez beaucoup de personnes aujourd’hui.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques veulent étudier plus d’ADN ancien dans des zones moins explorées comme la péninsule arabique pour voir si cette zone hybride était plus étendue. Ils cherchent aussi à savoir quand et à quelle fréquence ces croisements ont eu lieu.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Les premiers humains et les Néandertaliens se sont croisés plusieurs fois sur une grande partie de l’Europe et de l’Asie, créant une large zone d’ancêtres communs.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo estudio muestra que neandertales y primeros humanos se cruzaron en una vasta región
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos saben desde hace tiempo que los primeros humanos, llamados Homo sapiens, y los neandertales, un grupo cercano, se cruzaron. Por eso, la mayoría de las personas fuera de África tienen algo de ADN neandertal. Pero no se sabía dónde ni con qué frecuencia ocurrió esto.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Ginebra estudiaron 4,147 muestras antiguas de ADN humano de más de 1,200 lugares, algunas de hasta 44,000 años. Buscaron ADN neandertal en genomas humanos antiguos para descubrir dónde ocurrió el cruce. Su análisis mostró que la mezcla sucedió en una gran zona que va desde Europa occidental, pasando por el Mediterráneo oriental, hasta Asia occidental.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es importante porque muestra que los neandertales y los primeros humanos no solo se cruzaron en un lugar pequeño, sino en una amplia región durante miles de años. Cambia la forma en que entendemos la historia humana al revelar una gran “zona híbrida” donde las poblaciones se encontraron y compartieron genes. Esto ayuda a explicar por qué el ADN neandertal está presente en muchas personas hoy.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos quieren estudiar más ADN antiguo de áreas menos exploradas como la península arábiga para ver si la zona híbrida era aún más grande. También buscan saber cuándo y con qué frecuencia ocurrieron estos cruces.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Los primeros humanos y neandertales se cruzaron repetidamente en gran parte de Europa y Asia, creando una amplia zona de ancestros compartidos.

articles.title: Gaza: Limited Rafah crossing reopening sparks hope – but also ‘massive trepidation’
articles.summary: The reopening of the Rafah crossing in the southern Gaza Strip on Monday after more than a year is being met with both optimism and fear, a senior official with the UN agency that assists the Palestinian people, UNRWA, has said.
articles.content:
The sole border point with Egypt is a lifeline to the world – including for thousands of severely ill or injured Palestinians who require medical treatment outside the enclave, where last October’s fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hamas continues to hold.

The development comes, however, following reports of violence over the weekend, with the UN voicing concern over the killing of civilians and Israeli airstrikes.

Tweet URL

‘Competing dynamics’

“As we have seen so many times throughout this conflict, we’re seeing really competing dynamics here: on the one hand, positive progress when it comes to the re-opening of Rafah, and yet over the past 24 hours, 30 Palestinians were killed in airstrikes during a ceasefire,” Sam Rose, Acting Director of UNRWA Affairs in Gaza, told the BBC on Sunday.

“At the same time, international organizations that are equipped and qualified and capable of doing work, which is urgently needed, are continuing to face major, major constraints.”

For this reason, Palestinians in Gaza are feeling “massive trepidation – hope that people will be able to get out, but real, real fear for the future,” he said.

UNRWA remains on the ground delivering life-saving assistance in where “fear and uncertainty persist,” the agency said, noting that “access is limited, protection concerns persist, and humanitarian needs remain acute amid ongoing operational constraints.”

Limited movement

Reopening the Rafah crossing was an integral part of the 20-point peace plan put forward by US President Donald Trump last September, with the ceasefire announced days later.

For now, Israel will only allow some 50 Palestinians to enter and exit Gaza each day – and only on foot, international news agencies have reported.

The crossing will be coordinated with Egypt and supervised by the European Union (EU), according to the UN humanitarian affairs office, OCHA.

Returns will only be permitted for residents who left during the war and after obtaining prior authorisation from the Israeli security services, being checked by the EU at the Rafah crossing point and undergoing a second identification and control process in a designated corridor managed by the Israeli army in an area under its control.

Support for returnees

OCHA welcomed the reopening of the key border crossing, underscoring that “civilians must be allowed to leave and return voluntarily and safely, as international law requires.”

Over the weekend, the UN carried out an advance mission to assess road conditions.

The UN Development Programme (UNDP) is set to provide bus transportation for returnees from the internal checkpoint to Nassar hospital in Khan Younis, where several UN agencies and NGO partners have set up a reception area to provide them with support.

The reception desk is staffed by psychologists and protection specialists, while food, information materials and internet connectivity are available.

UN News A child arrives at Al-Amal Hospital in his wheelchair in an attempt to get treatment.

Medical evacuations

Monday also saw the World Health Organization (WHO) supporting medical evacuation efforts.

Some patients and their companions were able to exit Gaza directly to Egypt, while others transited through the Israeli-controlled Kerem Shalom border crossing

Israeli authorities approved the travel of only five wounded patients from a list of 27 names submitted to both the Egyptian and Israeli sides, according to Palestinian sources.

Treatment beyond borders

Families lined up in the courtyard of Al-Amal Hospital in the south of the Gaza Strip to bid farewell to sick relatives, and their travel companions, heading to Egypt to complete their treatment.

I hope to travel for treatment and return walking like other children - Youssef Awad

A UN News correspondent was on hand as buses began preparing to depart, carrying with them the hope that the wounded would return fully recovered.

A young boy called Youssef Awad, who uses a wheelchair, was optimistic that he would be able to walk and play again.

“I hope to travel for treatment and return walking like other children,” he said.

‘Expedite the process’

Another injured child, Ahmed Iyad Abu al-Khair, sat in a wheelchair beside his father, Iyad, awaiting his turn in the medical evacuation convoy heading to the Rafah crossing.

Ahmed’s head was covered with a white bandage, and he appeared unable to move while his father tried to comfort him.

“We hope that decision-makers and the World Health Organization will expedite the process and help us get my son Ahmed to travel to complete his treatment, as every hour he spends here affects his health.”

UN News Injured Palestinians in wheelchairs protest demanding permission to travel abroad for medical treatment.

Thousands still waiting

In a protest reflecting the extent of their despair, dozens of injured Palestinians staged a demonstration near the hospital, sitting in their wheelchairs and demanding an increase in the number of people allowed to travel daily which “should be in the hundreds” instead of 50.

“We have been waiting for the crossing to open since the beginning of the war, and like many others, we have not been lucky,” said Farid al-Qassas, an injured man.

We hope that everyone will hear us and save what remains of these patients - Farid al-Qassas

“In this building alone, there are about 100 patients in need of medical referrals, and the number of wounded waiting to travel reaches about 13,000 patients and injured people. We hope that everyone will hear us and save what remains of these patients.”

The last medical evacuation through the Rafah crossing was in May 2024. Overall, more than 18,500 patients in Gaza, including 4,000 children, are still waiting to access treatment abroad.

“The most effective option would be to resume referrals to the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and rehabilitate damaged health facilities in Gaza,” OCHA said.

Until then, UN Member States are urged “to accept more patients so that everyone receives the treatment that they need.”

Aid delivery update

The agency also stressed that “ultimately, essential humanitarian supplies must enter in sufficient quantities and with fewer restrictions through Rafah and other crossings.”

Between 23-29 January, at least 13,800 pallets of humanitarian aid managed by the UN and its partners were unloaded at crossing points.

Nearly 60 per cent of these shipments contained food, but also shelter items, school supplies, health items, fuel and nutritional kits.

Since the announcement of the ceasefire on 10 October, at least 272,000 pallets of humanitarian goods were unloaded, and 270,000 pallets were collected at the various crossing points.

articles.personality_title: Rafah crossing reopens, offering critical medical access for Gaza patients
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Rafah crossing is the only border between Gaza and Egypt. It has been closed for over a year, blocking many Palestinians from leaving Gaza, especially those needing urgent medical care outside the area.

**What happened** – On Monday, the Rafah crossing reopened in a limited way. Only about 50 people can cross each day, and only on foot. This reopening is being managed by Egypt, the European Union, and Israel, which controls who can leave and return. The United Nations and other groups are helping patients and their families travel safely.

**Impact** – This reopening is important because thousands of Palestinians in Gaza need medical treatment they can only get outside. For example, children like Youssef, who hopes to walk again after treatment, now have a chance to get help. UN agencies are providing support at hospitals and offering transportation. However, many people still face long waits and restrictions, and some injured Palestinians protested to ask for more people to be allowed to travel.

**What's next step** – The UN and international groups are working to speed up travel approvals and increase the number of patients allowed to leave. They also want to improve medical services inside Gaza and bring in more humanitarian supplies through the crossing. The reopening could lead to better health care access and more movement for people in Gaza if restrictions ease.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The limited reopening of the Rafah crossing marks a hopeful step for thousands of Gaza patients needing medical care abroad, despite ongoing challenges and restrictions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Réouverture du passage de Rafah : un accès vital aux soins pour les patients de Gaza
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le passage de Rafah est la seule frontière entre Gaza et l'Égypte. Il était fermé depuis plus d’un an, empêchant de nombreux Palestiniens, notamment ceux ayant besoin de soins médicaux urgents à l’extérieur, de quitter Gaza.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lundi, le passage de Rafah a rouvert de manière limitée. Environ 50 personnes peuvent traverser chaque jour, uniquement à pied. Cette réouverture est gérée par l’Égypte, l’Union européenne et Israël, qui contrôle les autorisations de sortie et de retour. L’ONU et d’autres organisations aident les patients et leurs familles à voyager en toute sécurité.

**Impact** – Cette réouverture est importante car des milliers de Palestiniens à Gaza ont besoin de soins médicaux qu’ils ne peuvent obtenir que hors de Gaza. Par exemple, des enfants comme Youssef, qui espère pouvoir marcher à nouveau après son traitement, ont désormais une chance d’être aidés. Les agences de l’ONU soutiennent les patients dans les hôpitaux et organisent leur transport. Cependant, beaucoup doivent encore attendre longtemps et faire face à des restrictions, ce qui a poussé certains blessés à manifester pour demander une augmentation du nombre de voyageurs.

**Prochaines étapes** – L’ONU et les groupes internationaux travaillent pour accélérer les autorisations de voyage et augmenter le nombre de patients autorisés à partir. Ils souhaitent aussi améliorer les services médicaux à Gaza et faire entrer plus d’aides humanitaires par le passage. Cette réouverture pourrait améliorer l’accès aux soins et la liberté de mouvement si les restrictions s’allègent.

**En une phrase** – La réouverture limitée du passage de Rafah offre une lueur d’espoir à des milliers de patients de Gaza nécessitant des soins médicaux à l’étranger, malgré les défis et restrictions persistants.
articles.personality_title_es: Reapertura del paso de Rafah ofrece acceso vital a tratamientos médicos para pacientes de Gaza
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El paso de Rafah es la única frontera entre Gaza y Egipto. Estuvo cerrado por más de un año, bloqueando a muchos palestinos, especialmente a quienes necesitan atención médica urgente fuera de Gaza.

**Qué pasó** – El lunes, el paso de Rafah reabrió de forma limitada. Solo unas 50 personas pueden cruzar cada día y solo a pie. La reapertura está coordinada por Egipto, la Unión Europea e Israel, que controla quién puede salir y regresar. Naciones Unidas y otros grupos están ayudando a los pacientes y sus familias a viajar con seguridad.

**Impacto** – Esta reapertura es importante porque miles de palestinos en Gaza necesitan tratamientos médicos que solo pueden recibir fuera. Por ejemplo, niños como Youssef, que espera poder caminar nuevamente tras su tratamiento, ahora tienen una oportunidad. Las agencias de la ONU brindan apoyo en hospitales y transporte. Sin embargo, muchas personas aún enfrentan largas esperas y restricciones, y algunos heridos protestaron para pedir que más personas puedan viajar.

**Próximos pasos** – La ONU y grupos internacionales trabajan para acelerar las aprobaciones de viaje y aumentar el número de pacientes que pueden salir. También buscan mejorar los servicios médicos dentro de Gaza y permitir la entrada de más ayuda humanitaria por el paso. La reapertura podría facilitar mejor acceso a la salud y movilidad si se reducen las restricciones.

**Resumen en una frase** – La reapertura limitada del paso de Rafah representa un paso esperanzador para miles de pacientes de Gaza que necesitan atención médica en el extranjero, a pesar de los desafíos y restricciones actuales.
